text: , also romanized as Kō-ō, was a Japanese era name (年号, nengō, lit. year name) of the Northern Court during the Nanboku-chō period after Kakei and before Meitoku. This period started in February 1389 and ended in March 1390.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Kō-ō" in Japan encyclopedia, p. 560. The pretender in Kyoto was .Nussbaum, "Go-Komatsu Tennō," p. 255; Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, pp. 317-318. Go-Komatsu's Southern Court rival in Yoshino during this time was .Nussbaum, "Go-Kameyama Tennō," pp. 254-255. ==Events of the Kōō era== * 1389 (Kōō 1): Yoshimitsu opposed by Kamakura kanrei Ashikaga Ujimitsu.Ackroyd, Joyce. 1982) Lessons from History: The "Tokushi Yoron", p. 329. * 1389 (Kōō 1, 7th month): Saioinji Sanetoshi died at the age of 56. He ha held the office of Minister of the Right (udaijin).Titsingh, p. 318; Mass, Jeffrey P. (2002). The Origins of Japan's Medieval World: Courtiers, Clerics, Warriors, and Peasants in the Fourteenth Century, p. 410. ==Southern Court nengō== * Genchū, 1384–1393 ==Related pages == * Muromachi period ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Kōō 1st 2nd 1389 1390 Preceded by: Kakei Northern Court nengō: Kōō Succeeded by: Meitoku Category:Japanese eras Category:1380s establishments in Japan Category:1390s disestablishments in Japan
title: Kōō (Nanboku-chō period)
